body:
@bolkedebruin I think this is in good shape. +1 from me. 

I accidentally bumped into the "max active runs" issue by testing the `example_passing_params_via_test_command` DAG over 8 days (same code as above)... turns out it has a `schedule_interval` of one minutes, so I immediately had 400 active DagRuns. Not sure if we want to address that as a core issue here (I know there was some discussion a while ago) but it's the only thing I'd flag as needing handling at some point (maybe a future PR).

I don't see a reason for using iterator too but I was not completely sure why the original author wanted it this way, hence the code split. I am totally fine with just replacing it with `default_options.items()` and `params.items()` . 

Also, I don't think that utf-8 encoding for dictionary keys and values in original code actually works (line # 130). The result of an encode() is a bytestring, and bytestrings cannot be used as dictionary keys nor can they be serialized by json.dumps() . I think it has to be removed
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/130362/17597616/7bf7c7b8-5fab-11e6-9705-6241db6502db.png)
@aoen @jlowin thx. Both good suggestions.. I'll go with making everything `1.`.. good solution.

@spektom Looks pretty good, but please address the code quality issues. 

Specifically, it looks like one of your format lines has extraneous nesting -- e.g. `format((...))` when it should be `format(..)`
@r39132 Can you point me to a line? I don't see any format() lines that I've added in this PR.

I agree, I wonder why -tp option is available only in test mode. It should be available on run too. Aside from just test/prod option, it is a critical requirement for certain workflows which are events driven. @jlowin looks like your change is not in the build.
LGTM
@aoen @jlowin fixed.
LGTM

Landscape seems out of its mind on this one. 

+1 merging
-s
@mistercrunch @artwr @plypaul

@jlowin thanks. I would like to leave the concurrency bit for when i move the backfill to a version that uses the scheduler. That should simplify things. 

Can you merge it for me?

With conf.test_mode(), the TEST_CONFIG overrides values in DEFAULT_CONFIG. I still see a lot of redundancy between those 2 config groups - i.e. a lot of fields with the same values. However, this is a great start. 

One suggestion. The function test_mode() can easily be confused with the variable of the same name, which can be found in various places like models.py (e.g. Task_instance states are not recorded in the db for test_mode). test_mode is set when someone calls "airflow test" using the CLI. 

People may confuse this method with returning a boolean of whether or code is being run via "airflow test". In light of that, I suggest changing the name of our method to something like configure_for_test().

That's my only concern. Also, the commit messages are a hair over 50 characters. Otherwise, please feel free to merge. Thx for improving the code.
@bolkedebruin To clarify, it's possible to have multiple DAG runs for the same (dag_id, execution_date, start_date)?

@r39132 Thanks for the comments!

One benefit of overwriting is that configurations no longer need to be duplicated in TEST_CONFIG if they already appear in DEFAULT_CONFIG -- TEST_CONFIG only needs to reflect values specific to testing.

Good call, I will change the function name.

Thanks for reviewing!
@bolkedebruin merged!
This looks super useful. Should _definitely_ add some docs to the .rst for this.
merging..

@jlowin thanks!

@plypaul it is. However if a previous dagrun exists this dagrun will be used. In case of a scheduled dagrun it will not be rewritten to a backfill run-id. This will need to be addressed separately. Probably some discussion is required on the approach. Does this answer your question?

@d-lee yeah, the double-edged sword of `contrib` is that it's easy for the community to contribute but it's not necessarily maintained or tested as well as `core`. My guess with regard to `iteritems` is that the author was used to the best-practices Python2 way, and it's fine to switch. You may be right about the utf-8 encoding, I don't use this Operator and don't have an easy way to test it.

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io?src=pr). Last update [11b4b08...5dbccfa](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/compare/11b4b087b334411a2a7bfb7bb4ef004050813748...5dbccfa650a24706d33cb7b15f45669ed6c30eac?src=pr)
LGTM

@d-lee  @jlowin sorry about the confusion, I used .iteritems() out of habits, but definitely agree .items() is the way to go.

As for the question about why encoding was used,  'bytes' type was only introduced in Python3, so .encode() in python2 encodes 'unicode' to 'str'. 

In particular, this code is probably encoding 'str' to 'str' for the most part, and it works for Python2 for a very evil reason. It sees that the object is not a unicode and first try to implicitly coerce it into unicode (which works since it's ascii by default) and then encode it into string... I think the reason I did this was because I was hitting unicode errors during testing for some reason with data that were passed in, but I cannot recall exactly.

I do agree that for this to be python3 compatible we should not be encoding it. As long as removing the encode will still work with 2, Im more than happy for the change! Thanks so much for the fix.

Just realized if 'notify' and 'card' were ever passed in to replace the default values, current implementation would break as well since they are not type 'str'. Oversight on my end. Thanks for the catch again.

thanks @jgao54! No need to apologize, `iteritems` is the correct Py2 way :) 

Elsewhere in Airflow I used the [python-future](http://python-future.org/index.html) library for cross-version compatibility, in particular around strings. It's been a while since I looked at it but I think that if you do `from builtins import str` you should get a cross-version `str()` function that you can apply in place of that `.encode()` call. But please test it, that's just from memory.

I'm surprised the original code worked at all -- doesn't Python complain if an iterator changes size during iteration? cc @bolkedebruin 

@yiqingj my preference would be to say `list(tis)` rather than `tis[:]` since it's more clear that it's making a copy.

@drknexus We are actively accepting updates to the list of companies. However, I do ask that you follow the contributor guidelines described [here](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AIRFLOW/Contributors%27+Guide).

Though it might seem heavy handed for such a trivial commit, consider it an introduction to contributing. Essentially, please create a JIRA and prefix your commit message (and this PR title) with `[AIRFLOW-XXX]` and place a link to the JIRA in this PR. Once done, we will happily merge.
@criccomini  @bolkedebruin  @jlowin  Updated this PR to reflect the changes from #1667
Will do. I'll close for now so I can get it all squared away.

@aoen interesting side effect: the debug logs seem to be swamping Travis (my browser is choking trying to load the logs in order to see what tests failed). Maybe you could add an env-var switch to turn off dependency logging, if only for testing?
@skudriashev LGTM -- thanks for helping clean this up
Welcome aboard!

This output can actually be pretty useful (I used it to debug some failing tests for the original PR). I think the right solution would be to modularize the travis-ci code (e.g. getting a test overview and then being able to drill down into the output of each test/module), or maybe suppress output from successful tests in CI. I also think there was talk about trying not to add unimportant flags to reduce branching complexity since it is already fairly high. @jlowin @mistercrunch what do you think?

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/130362/17680741/9ea5594e-62f6-11e6-97d9-f8c6270cc065.png)

Seems like all tests are failing?

@zodiac interesting point -- on the other hand, 50 characters is 50 characters. The tool does display the commit and asks the user to confirm they want to use it, or instructs them how to edit it, so I think it is up front about any changes that would be made...

Perhaps we can make this more reversible/obvious when changes take place.
@d-lee this looks good -- I assume you've tested in Py3? Is it possible to confirm that it runs in Py2 (I don't see why it wouldn't)?
It's been tested in Python 3.4 (full integration test with operator used in a dag). Also we run everything on Py3, there is no quick and easy way for me to test in Py2. Sorry

Still happening with fresh install.

airflow==1.7.1.3

Does not give good first impression when evaluating this. Can be circumvented by installing the hive thingy ..

Thanks @r39132 for the feedback. Just created and linked to JIRA issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-439

This PR is ready to be merged IMHO.
@r39132 added jira
New PR with clean commit history based of current master:  https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1743

I just started to look at this same issue -- thanks for fixing.  One suggestion would be to change the `schema='default'` argument for all the `get_*` functions to `schema=None` (e.g., [here](https://github.com/devonberry/incubator-airflow/blob/aebbd6c381fda40f801fb8b04c380ce9f137d918/airflow/hooks/hive_hooks.py#L599)).
Otherwise, users would have to do something like `get_data(hql, schema=None)` to get the existing behavior.  That is, the new implementation will use `'default'` as the schema, even if the stored db connection specifies a different schema.  I was also a little unsure of whether it was ok to add arguments to `get_conn` since this is an implementation of a BaseHook function which takes no arguments.

For reference, here is what I had started with: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/compare/master...askeys:hiveserver2_implement_schema_argument

I don't think it is a good idea to have this in views. This should be a proper rest api with versioning included. Please use a flask blueprint for this. It should be exposed as something like /api/v1/task_info

(Sorry see unit tests, rest stands)

@r39132 @normster I believe the logic here is incorrect, as it causes all scheduling to stop (eg starting task instances for running dagruns, changing dagrun state) https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-434
@bolkedebruin I believe the changes to the `/code` endpoint in `views.py` are incorrect, it will fail for dags with the same `__name__`. See https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-443

@zodiac hmn... interesting. The motivation for the original patch was to have `airflow backfill` abide by the max_active_runs parameter, but I see how this can result in the case you have pointed out. I will say that regardless of our patch, this limitation already happens to us in some of our dags. It sounds like our "fix" is making the problem more pronounced. Do you changes in this PR aim to work around our earlier fix? If so, I can shoot for a code review later today. I'm heading to the dentist right now.

@r39132 

> I will say that regardless of our patch, this limitation already happens to us in some of our dags. It sounds like our "fix" is making the problem more pronounced.

I'm not sure I understand, what is "this limitation"? I tested the test cases included in JIRA on the commit right before this PR, and the test case behaved as expected. I am not sure what is the best way to achieve what this PR does while avoiding the bug. I don't have a fix for it.

I'm curious how you avoided running into the bug in your production environment because in my testing, once `max_active_dag_runs` is hit the state of all dagruns will always stop changing, so nothing gets scheduled.
